question: Pipe A can fill a tank in 45 hrs and pipe B can fill it in 36 hrs. If both the pipes are opened in the empty tank. In how many hours will it be full?
solution:
Part filled A in 1 hr= (1/45)
Part filled B in 1 hr= (1/36)
Part filled by (A+B) together in 1 hr=(1/45)+(1/36)=1/20

So, The tank will be full in 20 hr.

question: If a pipe fills a tank in 6 h, then what part of the tank will the pipe fill in 1 h?
solution:
We know that, when a pipe fills a tank in m h, then the part of tank filled in 1 h = 1/m
Here, m = 6
∴ Required part of the tank to be filled in 1h = 1/6 part

question: A cistern is normally filled in 8 hours but takes two hours longer to fill because of a leak in its bottom. If the cistern is full, the leak will empty it in ?
solution:
Work done by leak in 1 hour = (1/8 - 1/10) = 1/40
∴ The leak will empty the cistern in 40 hours.

question: A pipe can empty a tank in 12 minutes and another pipe can empty it in 16 minutes. If both the pipes are opened simultaneously, find the time in which a full tank is emptied ?
solution:
Let the pipe which can empty the tank in 12 minutes be Pipe A
And the pipe which can empty the tank in 16 minutes be Pipe B.
Volume of tank = 1 unit
Pipe A can empty 1/12 of tank in 1 minute
Pipe B can empty 1/16 of tank in 1 minute
Together, they can empty (1/12 + 1/16) of tank in 1 minute
= (4 + 3) / (48) of tank in 1 minute
= 7/48 of tank in 1 minute
Time taken to empty the full tank = 48/7 minutes

question: A cistern is normally filled in 8 hrs. but takes 2 hrs. longer to fill because of a leak in its bottom. If the cistern is full, the leak will empty it in ?
solution:
Let the leak empty the tank in x hours
In 1 hour, the cistern can be filled by 1/8 part
But, due to the leak, it is getting filled in 1/10 part in 1 hour
Hence, 1/8 - 1/10 = 1/x
Solving, we get x = 40 hours

question: An inlet pipe fills 1/8 part of a tank in 1 h. How much time will the pipe take to fill the empty tank?
solution:
Let the required time be x hours. 
Then, the inlet pipe can fill \(\frac{1}{x}\) part of the tank in 1 hour. 
It is given that the inlet pipe fills \(\frac{1}{8}\) part of the tank in 1 hour. 
So, we have \(\frac{1}{x} = \frac{1}{8}\). 
Solving this equation, we get x = 8 hours. 
Therefore, the pipe will take 8 hours to fill the empty tank.

question: An outlet pipe can empty a cistern in 3 h. In what time will the pipe empty two-third part of the cistern?
solution:
Let the capacity of the cistern be C, and the time taken by the outlet pipe to empty the cistern be x hours. 
Then, the outlet pipe can empty \(\frac{1}{x}\) part of the cistern in 1 hour. 
It is given that the outlet pipe can empty the cistern in 3 hours. 
So, we have \(\frac{1}{x} = \frac{1}{3}\). 
Solving this equation, we get x = 3 hours. 
To empty two-third of the cistern, the outlet pipe needs to empty \(\frac{2}{3}\) of the capacity of the cistern. 
So, the outlet pipe will take \(\frac{2}{3} \times 3 = 2\) hours to empty two-third part of the cistern.

question: An outlet pipe can empty a cistern in 30 min, then what part of the cistern will it empty in 1 min?
solution:
We know that when a pipe empties a cistern in n minutes, then the part of the cistern emptied in 1 minute is \(\frac{1}{n}\).

Here, the time taken to empty the cistern is 30 minutes, so the part of the cistern emptied in 1 minute is \(\frac{1}{30}\). Therefore, option C is correct.

question: Three pipes A, B and C can fill a tank separately in 8 h,10 h and 20h, respectively. Find the time taken by all the three pipes to fill the tank when these pipes are opened together ?
solution:
Part filled by A in 1 h = 1/8
Part filled by B in 1 h = 1/10
Part filled by C in 1 h = 1/20
Part filled by (A + B + C) in 1 h = 1/8 + 1/10 + 1/20
= (5 + 4 + 2)/40 = 11/40
∴ Required time to fill the tank = 40/11 h
= 37/11 h

question: A tap can fill a tank in 16 minutes and another can empty it in 8 minutes. If the tank is already half full and both the taps are opened together, the tank will be ?
solution:
Part emptied in 1 min. = (1/8 - 1/16) = 1/16
∴ Time taken to empty the full tank = 16 min.
Hence, time taken to empty the half tank = 8 min.

question: A cistern can be filled by two pipes A and B in 4 hours and 6 hours respectively. When full, the tank can be emptied by a third pipe C in 8 hours . If all the taps be turned on at the same time, the cistern will be full in ?
solution:
Net filling in 1 hour = (1/4 + 1/6 - 1/8) = 7/24
∴ Time taken to fill the cistern = (24/7) hrs. = 3 hrs. 26 min.

question: One tap can fill a cistern in 2 hours and another can empty the cistern in 3 hours. How long will they take to fill the cistern if both the taps are opened ?
solution:
Net filling in 1 hour = (1/2 - 1/3) = 1/6
∴ Time taken to fill the cistern = 6 hours

question: A pipe can fill a tank in x hours and another can empty it in y hours. They can together fill it in (y > x) ?
solution:
Net filling in 1 hour = (1/x - 1/y) = (y - x) / xy
∴ Time taken to fill the tank = xy / (y - x) hrs.
